) Audience: All IRS employees, former employees, personal administrators for estates of former IRS employees and IRS personnel that manage the adminis- trative waiver program. (

) The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Administrative debt - A non-tax debt resulting from administrative actions. b. Appeal - An administrative proceeding in which the responsible party requests an independent review of the debt. c. Debt - An amount of money, funds or property that has been determined by an agency official to be due to the United States from any person, or- ganization or entity, except another federal agency. d. Debt collection - The recovery of non-tax debts owed to the IRS. e. Debtor - A person, organization or entity, except another federal agency, that owes an amount of money, funds or property to the United States. f. Deciding official - An individual who has authority to determine whether a requested waiver may be provided. g. Delinquent - A debt status signifying that the amount owed was not paid by the date of the IRS initial billing notice unless other satisfactory payment arrangements have been made. h. Erroneous payment - An incorrect payment, usually arising as the result of an administrative processing error. i. Overpayment - Any payment to an employee that is more than the amount owed to the employee. j. Penalty - A punitive charge assessed on a delinquent debt. The rate is not to exceed
% per year and is assessed on the portion of the debt remaining delinquent more than
days (Title
, USC, Section

)). k. Principal - An amount owed by the debtor to the IRS, excluding interest, administrative costs, penalty, fees and prepaid charges. l. Restitution - Payment by a party causing a loss, damage or injury to the injured party to restore the injured party to the status existing before suffering the loss, damage or injury. m. Salary offset - The process of collecting a percentage or a set dollar amount of a debtor’s current salary to help satisfy a delinquent non-tax debt. n. Waiver - In accordance with an appropriate statute, the cancellation, remission, forgiveness or non-recovery of a non-tax debt owed by a debtor to an agency, generally at the debtor’s request. o. Waiver request - A petition seeking relief from paying a debt. (

) A debt may only be waived for: a. An erroneous payment of pay and allowances, travel, transportation or relocation expenses and allowances. b. An employee’s non-compliance with the terms of a service agreement where the IRS demands repayment of the costs the IRS spent on the employee’s behalf. (

) A waiver will not be granted where there is any proof of fraud, misrepresenta- tion, fault or lack of good faith on the part of the debtor. Fault may exist if the debtor knew or should have known an error or omission existed. For example, the reimbursement of airport parking expenses in excess of the amount allowed under the Federal Travel Regulation and the underwithholding of health insurance premiums are situations in which the debtor should have known an error existed. (
) The debtor must submit a waiver request no later than

days from the receipt of the demand letter sent to the debtor in accordance with established procedures for an erroneous payment of pay and allowances, travel, transpor- tation or relocation expenses and allowances. (
) The debtor must provide a written justiﬁcation for a waiver request along with supporting documentation, if any. (

) The debtor must include the following information for both the initial waiver request and any appeal: a. Debtor’s name b. Debtor’s SEID c. Amount of debt d. Amount requested to be waived e. Reason or justiﬁcation for the waiver request or appeal f. Receipts or vouchers redacted to omit any social security numbers or bank account numbers if the waiver request is for travel, transportation relocation expenses and allowances g. ) The IRS suspends collection of a debt during the waiver review process. All interest, penalty and administrative costs may continue to accrue and are added to the amount of the debt if the waiver request is denied. (

) Factors considered for a waiver of debt relating to pay and allowances, transportation and relocation pay and allowances include but are not limited a. Whether the debtor knew of or should have known of the erroneous payment. b. The time elapsed between the erroneous payment, the subsequent discovery of the error and notiﬁcation to the debtor. c. Whether the debtor received an unearned beneﬁt or was unduly enriched. d. Whether the debtor has relinquished a valuable right or changed positions for the worse due to the erroneous payment. (

) Factors the IRS considers when evaluating a debtor’s waiver request of a training debt: a. Whether the situation presents extenuating circumstances. b. Whether the debtor could have foreseen or anticipated the situation. c. Whether the debtor acted to mitigate the loss to the IRS (such as a timely withdrawal from the course where the debtor obtained a tuition refund). (
